Comment: Brendan Buck, a communications strategist who has worked for Paul Ryan and John Boehner, writes in a guest essay for Times Opinion:  >After more than 100 days of President Trump marked by overreach and economic self-immolation, congressional Republicans need a reset to save their political fortunes. Representative Mike Johnson, the House speaker, is banking on a spending and tax cut package to provide that jolt, and numerous House committees are now working quickly to stitch together a bill he has pledged to deliver to Mr. Trump before Independence Day.  >This ‚Äúone big, beautiful bill,‚Äù as Mr. Trump has called it, contains most of the president‚Äôs legislative agenda. Indeed, the strategy is making the bill too big to fail, betting that wavering members will not be willing to vote against it and deliver the leader of their own party such a stinging defeat.  >But what if it does pass and voters barely take notice?  Read the full essay [here, for free](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/05/07/opinion/johnson-thune-tariffs-reconciliation.html?unlocked_article_code=1.FU8.35NR.hoedBxsGA6rM&smid=re-nytopinion), even without a Times subscription.

Comment: "But the reality is it‚Äôs no cut at all for most people. The rates they are preserving have been in place for more than seven years now."  Right, these taxes have been in place for 7 years, so passing this bill isn't going to give anybody any relief. Instead, we'll be left feeling the pain of higher prices, lower medicaid benefits, etc. Those are primarily issues felt by the poorest, and GUESS WHO THEY VOTED FOR.  "Passing a bill to prevent tax rates from going up is a necessary action. But congressional leaders should not kid themselves. Unless they ‚Äî or the markets ‚Äî can convince the president to back down on tariffs, this ‚Äúone big, beautiful bill‚Äù may feel more like thin gruel to voters."  Right, tariffs are going to absolutely get them destroyed in the midterms. These guys are letting Trump do them and they're basically building their own political coffins here. Everyone's top issue come midterms is going to be tariffs.
